Mean Squared Error 

 

But this is the training mean squared error, and actually we're more interested in test data: 

When x0 and y0 are test data. 

 

But what if no test data exists? Do we minimize training error? No, because there's often a big difference between training error and test error.  

Lower is training data, upper is test data. So if you fit it really flexibly, it'll look great in the fit but tests will be whack. Overfit. Blue squares minimize the test mean squared error. 

But TBH, usually there's no test data available. 

 

So that's the Bias/Variance tradeoff.  

 

The expected test MSE can be broken up into 3 parts. The proof is too complicated, so just trust: 

    

     Expected test MSE           =         ------              +    ---------------              +     --------- 

 

 

This refers to the average test MSE that we would obtain if we repeatedly estimated f using a large number of training sets, and tested each at x0.  

What we learn from this is that, to minimize test error, we need to optimize low variance and low bias.  

 

But what's the variance and bias of a statistical learning method? Variance is the amount by which f_hat would change if we estimated it using a different training data set. More flexible statistical methods have higher variance. Bias is the error from approximating a complicated real life problem with a simpler model.  

 

Classification 

Now quantifying the accuracy of our estimate f_hat is the training error rate, the proportion of mistakes if we apply f_hat to the training observations:  

 But of course even better is the test error rate 

 

So here's how we do a good job, obviously: Assign each observation to the most likely class, given predictor values. Duh. So, whichever of these values is largest: 

The probability that Y is j when X is xo. We call this a conditional probability, and such a classifier is a Bayes classifier.  

A Bayes decision boundary is where the probability is exactly 50%. It's the dashed line here:

K NEAREST NEIGHBORS 

But computing the Bayes classifier is usually impossible because we don't know the true distribution of Y given X, so we can't say what the probability of Y=j | X=xo is. Bayes is an unattainable gold standard, that bastard. So instead, we have to estimate the probability.  

 

Here's how: Given a value K, and a test observation xo, the KNN identifies the K points nearest to xo in the training data (N0), then it estimates the probability that Y = j as the fraction of these K points which abide by Y = j: 

 

 

The probability that Y = j given that X = xo is equal to the sum of all of the indicator variables (either 1 when y = j or 0 otherwise) of those K nearby values, divided by K. Then, x0 gets classified to the class with the largest probability. 

Using too small of a K makes too wiggly of a line (low bias, high variance), and too high of a K makes too rigid of a line (high bias, low variance). Thus, find the best K: 

   

 

 

CHAPTER 3 - Linear Regression 

 

 

Least Squares - A method for fitting a linear regression line. 

Residual (e) - difference between the observed response value and the predicted response value. 

 

Residual sum of squares 

OR 

 

So we choose our Betas to minimize the RSS: 

 

But so ok, any one estimate from some limited data will be slightly inaccurate - but how inaccurate? We calculate this by computing the standard error, SE: 

where sigma is standard deviation of each of the yi.  

 

Standard error tells us the amount that our estimate differs from the actual value. Here it is for our Betas: 

 

Sigma isn't known but the estimate of sigma can be calculated - called the residual standard error.  

 

Standard error is used to compute confidence intervals. A 95% confidence interval is defined as a range of values such that with 95% probability the range will contain the true unknown value of the parameter.  

 

 

Hypothesis Testing 

Standard error is used to compare H0 and Ha (alternative to the null). To test the null hypothesis, we need to determine whether B_hat1 is sufficiently far from zero that we can be confident that B1 is non-zero. If the standard error is small, we can conclude even a very small B1 is not = 0.  

 

T Statistic 

This measures the number of standard deviations that B_hat1 is away from 0. If there is no relationship between X and Y, then this equation will have a t-distribution with n - 2 degrees of freedom (?). The probability of observing any number equal or larger than |t| is the p-value.  

 

Here's the p-value: A small p-value means it's unlikely to observe such a substantial association between the predictor and the response due to chance, in the absence of any real association between the predictor and the response. Thus, we can reject the null hypothesis. 5% and 1% are normal p-value cutoffs. When n = 30, that corresponds to t-statistics of around 2 and 2.75. 

 

Ok so now we've rejected the null hypothesis and accepted the alternative hypothesis. Let's quantify the extent to which the model fits the data, using these two things: The Residual Standard Error (RSE) and the R2 statistic.  

 

RSE is an estimate of the standard deviation of epsilon - the amount that the response will deviate from the true regression line.  

 

 

R2 statistic - an alternative to RSE, which is more easily understandable because it takes the form of a proportion of variance explained - it's always between 0 and 1.  

 

 

TSS: Total sum of squares - measures the total variance in the response Y. So, R2 is the proportion of variability in Y that can be explained using X.  

 

Multiple Linear Regression 

 

Like before, we use Least Squares to estimate these Beta parameters - minimizing the sum of squared residuals.  F-statistic, F-test: 

 

The F statistic will be 1 when there is no relationship between the response and the predictors, and greater than 1 when there is. When n is large, F-statistic can be smaller, but when n is small we need a larger F-statistic. We can calculate a p-value associated with this F-statistic, and determine whether to reject the null.  

 

But now instead of proving whether all of the Beta values are 0 or not, let's prove if a smaller subset q of the coefficients are zero. It's similar to before. 

Ok but if we've proven the t statistic and the associated p-value for each of the p predictors indicate that there's significance, why do we need the F-statistic? Well, when p gets very large, there's a chance that some of the p values will be less than 0.05, even in the absence of any true association. The F-statistic adjusts for the number of predictors, so it doesn't suffer from this problem. 

 

Deciding on the important variables 

It's likely that some of the predictors are important but not all of them. We need to perform variable selection. We can't try all of the possible combinations of predictors, so here's how we choose the correct ones: 

Forward selection:  First start with the null - an intercept and no predictors - then we fit a linear regression for each of the predictors. The one with the lowest RSS (residual sum of squares) gets added to the model. Then, we add to that model the variable that results in the lowest RSS for the two variable model. And so on. 

Backward selection: Similar to before, but this time we start with all the variables in the model, and remove the one with the largest p-value. Re-fit the model, and remove largest p-value again. Go until a p-value threshold is met. 

Mixed selection: go forwards until a p-value is exceeded, then remove that one, and continue forwards (and backwards) until you're satisfied. 

 

A prediction interval includes the confidence interval - how close our estimate is to the true function that describes the data (reducible error) and the uncertainty of how much any individual point will differ from the population regression plane (the irreducible error).

Assumptions of the linear, multi-parameter model 

The linear regression model assumes the relationship between predictors and response are additive and linear.  

 

Removing the additive assumption: The predictors are related. This is called synergy or interaction. To account for this mathematically, we introduce an interaction term, which is the product of X1 and X2.  

equals 

 

 and interaction between a qualitative and a quantitative variable is similar. 

 

Removing the assumption of linear relationships: 

Polynomial regression is like this:  

 which is actually still linear, as B1 and B2 are multiplied by X1 = horsepower and X2 = horsepower2 . Including higher exponents on horsepower just makes things more wiggly.  

 

Problems with fitting linear regression models: 

  1. 1.Non-linearity of the response-predictor relationships 

    1. a.Residual plots are helpful for identifying non-linearity. Plotting residuals vs xi or ybari should have no pattern, but if it does, the linear model is suspect.  

  2. 2.Correlation of error terms 

    1. a.We assume residuals are uncorrelated. This can make our confidence intervals incorrect, and our p-values less significant than we believed. This happens for time series data, when the time between samples is close, the error is similar.  

  3. 3.Non-constant variance of error terms 

    1. a.We've assumed that the variance of the error terms is constant, and everything relies upon that. But sometimes the variance increases with the value of the response - heteroscedasticity - which looks like a funnel shape in the residual plot. To fix this, we transform Y with a concave function like logY.  

  4. 4.Outliers 

    1. a.They can mess up your RSE, which is used to compute confidence intervals. To decide which outliers to disregard, we plot the studentized residuals - divide each residual by its estimated standard error.  

  5. 5.High-leverage points 

    1. a.Like an outlier, but we have an unusual predictor X. These have a sizeable impact on the estimated regression line. To remedy this we compute a leverage statistic. 

  6. 6.Collinearity 

    1. a.Two or more predictor variables are closely related to one another. We can see this when we plot two predictors against each other. I don't understand what they're saying.

CHAPTER 4 - Classification 

If you want to model a classification problem with linear regression, you're out of luck unless there's just two classes. Then, you can use a dummy variable - such as 0 for spam and 1 for ham, and fit a linear regression. However, we can get identical results using linear discriminant analysis.  

 

Logistic Regression 

This models the probability that the response Y belongs to a particular category.  

 

The probability of default being yes given a particular balance. 

 

So what's the model we'll use? Well, we need it to stay between 0 and 1 (as this is a binary case, where the two classes are defined as 0 and 1). Let's use the logistic function:

Estimating the Logistic Regression Coefficients 

Let's use maximum likelihood. Here's the idea: Estimate Bo and B1 such that the predicted probability of default for each individual corresponds to the individual's observed default status (in the training data). This seems obvious. Here's a likelihood function, which we want to maximize:  

 

"The likelihood, as a function of Beta_not and Beta_1, is equal to the product of the probabilities related to each individual xi, times the product of 1 minus the probabilities  related to each individual xi." 

Don't worry too much about this equation, just use it.

Linear Discriminant Analysis 

Modelling the distribution of the predictors X separately in each of the response classes (i.e. given Y), and then use Bayes' theorem to flip these around into estimates for Pr(Y=k|X=x).  

 

 

(also called p_k(x)) 

Where pi_k is the overall or prior probability that a randomly chosen observation comes from the kth class and f_k(x) is the probability that X = x when Y = k, which is called a density function. We need to find f_k(x) to calculate this.  

 

Assumptions: the density function is "normal" or "Gaussian." That the sigma^2 is the same for all K classes.  

 

Ultimately, this all comes down to finding which class has the largest delta: 

 

But we don’t know many of these values, so we have to estimate them. We do so using the Linear Discriminant Analysis method (LDA), estimating pi_k, mu_k, and sigma^2 like so:  

LDA for p>1 (multiple predictors) 

 

Quadratic discriminant analysis 

Like LDA in that it assums that each class has a Gaussian distribution. Different from LDA in that each class has its own covariance matrix. Thus, the Bayes classifier assigns an observation X = x to the class for which: 

Is largest. Now x is a quadratic function (thus QDA).  

Why use LDA vs QDA? The bias-variance trade-off. QDA estimates a separate covariance matrix for each class, requiring K more calculations of parameters, which is a lot. But LDA is less flexible, thus having lower variance which can be good - but if covariances aren't actually common, then LDA suffers from high bias.  

 

Naïve Bayes 

Useful when p is very large. 

 

 

A comparison of classification methods 

Logistic regression, LDA, QDA, and KNN.  

LDA and logistic regression are very similar, except that logistic regression finds B0 and B1 using maximum likelihood, whereas LDA uses the estimated mean and variance from a normal distribution. They both produce linear decision boundaries. LDA performs better when its assumptions are true, logistic regression otherwise.  

KNN is great for non-linear decision boundaries. But we don't get any coefficients from it, so it can't tell us which predictors are important. 

QDA is a compromise between KNN and LDA/log reg.  

 

CHAPTER 5 - Resampling Methods 

 

The Validation Set Approach - Assessed using MSE. Randomly divide the available data into a training set and a validation set. However, if you randomly divide, fit, and measure MSE, you can get very different amounts of MSE each time: 

Problems with this method: It's highly variable, and it only uses half the data to train the model. If we used the whole dataset, our true "test error" would be much lower. 

 

Cross Validation 

Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation (LOOCV): Only one data point is used in the validation set, and the model is fit on the rest of the n-1 observations. Then, MSE of this one held out data point is calculated (y1 - yhat1)^2. Then, repeat this procedure for every single datapoint in the model, and finally calculate the test error by averaging the n resulting MSE's. 

Advantages: Less bias. Smaller test error. Only gives one definitive result.  

Disadvantages: Expensive, time consuming. (But, when using least squares linear or polynomial regression, we can use a shortcut:  

 where hi is the leverage defined in 3.37: 

 Thus the residuals with high leverage are inflated.) 

 

LOOCV can be used with logistic regression, linear discriminant analysis, and other models (although 5.2 doesn't always work). 

 

K-Fold Cross-Validation:  

 

Randomly dividing the set of observations into k groups, or "folds," of equal size. Train on a portion of the data, MSE is calculated with the test data, and the method is repeated k times. The final CV estimate is calculated: 

K=5 and k=10 are the most popular. The advantage is computational.  

 

The Bootstrap 

Used to quantify the uncertainty associated with a given estimator or statistical learning method.  

 

So, we can emulate new sample sets, so that we can estimate the variability of a term without generating additional samples. 

The key here is sampling with replacement, which helps to simulate the actual population. We take a sample of the data set and estimate our desired parameter from it, then take many more of these samples, and keep estimating. We then compute the standard error of these estimates.  

 

CHAPTER 6 Linear Model Selection and Regularization 

Let's replace least squares! We can get better prediction accuracy and model interpretability. 

 

 

Subset Selection: Identifying a subset of the p predictors that are related to the response. Then, use least squares.  

 

Here's the process: Fit every possible model. Every p=1, p=2, to p=p. Then, select the best one. How to select the best one? Smallest RSS, or equivalently, the largest R^2, from training data. Then, calculate cross validated prediction error (Cp), BIC, or adjusted R^2.  

 

Let's phrase this differently: fit all (P / K), choose the best of each subset size with RSS, then choose the best of those with cross validation. 

 

This is incredibly computationally intensive. 

 

Stepwise Selection:  

Forward Stepwise Selection: Begin with no predictors, then add predictors one at a time until all are in the model, based on which is most beneficial. 

Backward Stepwise Selection: Begin with the full least squares model containing all p predictors, then iteratively remove the least useful predictor, one at a time. 

Hybrid Approach: Move forward, but also remove variables that no longer provide an improvement after these additions. 

 

Choosing the optimal model: Focus on test error, not training error!  

 

Two common approaches: 

  1. 1.Indirectly estimate test error by making an adjustment to the training error to account for overfitting bias 

    1. a.Cp, AIC, BIC, and adjusted R^2 

  2. 2.Directly estimate test error using a validation set or cross validation. 

 

 

 

Cp, AIC, BIC, and Adjusted R^2: 

Cp:  

 

Essentially, this statistic adds a penalty (relative to the number of predictors used, d) to the training RSS in order to adjust for the fact that the training error tends to underestimate the test error.  

 

AIC:  

Defined for models fit by maximum likelihood.  

 

BIC:  Baysien Information Criterium.  

This places a heavier penalty on models with many variables, and selects smaller models than Cp. 

 

Adjusted R^2:  

You want this to be large, thus you want d to be small.  

 

Shrinkage Methods: Use all p predictors, but shrink the predictors towards zero (aka regularization). This reduces variance. 

 

Ridge Regression: Instead of calculating beta's by minimizing RSS, we minimize:  

where lambda is a tuning parameter to be determined separately. It's a shrinkage penalty. 

When lambda = 0, the penalty has no effect. When lambda goes to infinity, the coefficients go to zero. But not beta_0.  

This is an L2 penalty. 

Always standardize the predictors before performing ridge regression. 

Large lambdas decreases variance and increases bias, so it's great when least squares has high variance, such as when p > n. 

A disadvantage is that ridge regression still uses all of the p predictors, the beta coefficients don't go all the way to zero. 

 

The Lasso: Overcomes the problem with ridge regression that it doesn't bring any coefficients all the way to zero: 

This is an L1 penalty. 

This will cause some of the coefficient estimates to be exactly zero when lambda is sufficiently large, thus performing variable selection - aka sparse models.  

 

' 

Least squares is Beta hat, the blue diamond and circle are the lasso and ridge regression constraints, red ellipses are the contours of the RSS (every point on an ellipse has the same RSS). Bigger ellipses mean higher RSS. Where the blue and red meet is the lasso and ridge regression coefficient estimates. 

Because the lasso has corners, the ellipses will often meet the lasso constraint on an axis, meaning one of the coefficients equals zero. 

 

The lasso will beat ridge regression when many of the predictors are truly unrelated to the response, but ridge will beat lasso when the predictors are all related to the response. 

 

Selecting the tuning parameter lambda: Cross validation, of course. 

 

Elastic Net (not in text book): For redundant variables, where (for example) two predictors are identical, then their two coefficients can be (2+2) or (1+3) etc. This combines L1 and L2 regularizations.  

 

Dimension Reduction Methods: Project the p predictors into a M-dimensional subspace, where M < p, by finding linear combinations of the variables.  

ZM  when M < P, Z represents combinations of the p # of X predictors:  

Thus creating:  

Now there are M thetas, not p betas, which makes it easier. Here's a transformation:  

This is good when p is large relative to n, because choosing M << P really reduces variance.  

 

Theta is the new beta, z is the new x, z is determined by our choice of phi. 

 

But the big question is, how do we choose ZM or, equivalently, phijm's? Here's two ways: 

 

  1. 1.Principal components regression 

First let's discuss Principal Component Analysis: PCA is a technique for reducing the dimension of a matrix. Step 1: Find a new axis for which the data has the most variance:  

Phi are the coefficients defining the equation of the green line above.  

(We're also minimizing the distance from the points to the line by choosing the right line.) 

Next, we rotate the axis so that the line is the new x axis. The first principal component score is the new x distance of a point from zero (with zero being the point at (mean X1, mean X2)). This score has combined the two predictor values!  

Ok so this is the FIRST principal component. The second principal component Z2 is a linear combination of the variables that are uncorrelated with Z1 and have largest variance. It's perpendicular, as seen by the blue line above. W can only predict as many components as we have predictors, and they get less relevant as they go on. 

 

Now we can introduce PCR. This approach involves constructing M principal components (ZM) to be used as predictors in our linear regression model.  

PCR performs best when the first few principal components are sufficient to capture most of the variation in the predictors as well as the relationship with the response.  

Note: This is not feature selection! It is dimension reduction, it still considers all p original features, although it uses M to represent them. Further, this is all decided by the predictors, not the response - it is unsupervised. This is a potential fault.  

  1. 2.Partial least squares: A supervised alternative to PCR. It considers the response variable in the selection of Z's. It is done by setting each phi equal to the coefficient from the simple linear regression of Y and X.  

Thus, PLS will be slightly different than PCA because it is consider the predictor's relationship to the response as well as their relationship to each other.

CHAPTER 8: Tree Based Methods 

Stratifying or segmenting the predictor space into a number of simple regions. We then use the mean or mode of the training observations in the region to which a test sample belongs. The splitting rules used to segment the predictor space are displayed in a tree, so these are known as decison tree methods. They are highly interpretable, but are not as accurate as supervised methods from chapter 6. Thus, we can create multiple trees which are combined to yield a single consensus prediction via bagging, random forests, and boosting. However, this will make things much less interpretable.  

 

Terminal nodes or leaves of the tree are the final regions, which are labeled with a (regression) value or a class. They are at the bottom of the tree. Internal nodes are the decision points within the tree, usually less than / greater than splits. Branches connect the nodes.  

 

Regression and Classification Trees 

Here's how to build a tree: 

  1. 1.Divide the predictor space (containing all X values) into J distinct, non-overlapping regions Rj. We choose boxes for these shapes, for simplicity. The goal is to choose boxes to minimize RSS. This is computationally intensive though, so we decide to take a top-down, greedy approach known as recursive binary splitting: start with 1 big region, then the best split is made at each particular step without considering potentially better future splits (greedy). It just splits it depending on best RSS: 

Now there's two spaces, consider them and split one of them, now there's three, consider them and split one of them, now there's four. Stop at a pre-decided point, such as when each region has 5 observations. 

  1. 2.Every observation in a region Rj gets the same prediction, the mean of the training response observations in Rj.  

 

Regression Trees 

Tree pruning: The above process is likely to over-fit the data. One way to fix this is to decide that each split must decrease RSS a certain amount, and if it doesn't, it won't make the split. But, this isn't ideal. Even better is to grow a very large tree T0 and then prune it back to create a subtree. The way of deciding the best subtree is cross validation, but we can't consider every possible subtree. We need a better method. 

 

Cost complexity pruning is one method. We use (alpha) to do so.  

 

Alpha is chosen with cross validation.  

 

Classification Trees 

Instead of the mean response of the training observations in a terminal node, here we assign an observation to the most commonly occurring class of training observations.  

Here what's also interesting other than the prediction corresponding to a particular node is the class proportions within a region.  

Instead of minimizing RSS, we minimize the classification error rate. However, this is not sensitive enough, so we use two other methods: 

  1. 1.The Gini index: 

    1. 1.

Is a measure of total variance across the K classes. It is a measure of "purity" - a small value indicates that a node is predominately of one class.   

  1. 2.Entropy - an alternative to the Gini index:  

 

  1. 1.

D will be small if the node is pure.   

 

Some predictors are classification predictors. 

Sometimes the leaves have the same value, but then why split there? To enhance node purity. A more pure region makes us more confident of a classification when a test response falls in that region. This is done because Gini and Entropy select for purity. 

 

Trees vs Linear Models: Trees are better for nonlinear and complex relationships. They're also better for visualization.  They don't require dummy variables for qualitative predictors. However, they're not as good at prediction, and they're non-robust: A small change in data can create a large change in the tree. 

 

(end midterm material) 

 

Bagging 

A method for dealing with the high variance that often occurs when training decision trees, by using bootstrapping. "Bootstrap aggregation" aka bagging.  

The idea is that averaging a set of observations (samples) reduces variance, compared to a single observation. Thus, bootstrap to take repeated samples (with replacement) from the single training set and make B different bootstrapped training data sets. Train the method on each training set, and average the predictions, giving:  

This is bagging. To perform it for regression trees, grow B different trees from each bootstrapped dataset very deep and do not prune them, then average the predictions made from them. Each tree will have high variance but low bias, and averaging the trees will reduce variance.  

 

The process for classification trees is similar. Record the class predicted by each of the B trees, then take a majority vote. 

 

Out-of-Bag Error Estimate: A possible alternative to cross validation. Because each tree makes use of only about 2/3 of the training data, there is a left over 1/3 that can be used for testing. This data is referred to as out of bag. We can estimate what the class of the ith observation is by using only the trees in which that observation was out of bag, giving about B/3 observations.  

 

Random Forests 

Random forests improve over bagging by helping to decorrelate the trees. As with bagging, many decision trees are built on bootstrapped training samples. But, when building the decision trees, each time a split in a tree is considered, a random sample of m predictors is chosen as split candidates from the full set of p predictors. The split only uses 1 of these m predictors. Usually, we choose m as sqrt(p).  

 

Here's the rationale: it injects variation into the trees, lowering the correlation between the trees. When these uncorrelated trees are averaged, you get a more clear picture of the truth than when averaging many nearly identical trees. It's good to use a small m when there's many correlated predictors.  

 

 

Boosting 

Boosting is similar to bagging, except that the trees are grown sequentially - each is grown using information from previously grown trees. There's no bootstrapping here, instead each tree is fit on a modified version of the original data set. The boosting approach "learns slowly." It refines each iterative model by fitting a decision tree to the residuals from the model, not the response Y. It then adds this new decision tree into the fitted function to update the residuals.  

 

It includes: 

The number of trees B. Unlike bagging and random forests, if B is too large overfitting can occur. It is chosen with cross validation. 

The shrinkage parameter (lambda), a small positive number, which determines the rate at which boosting learns.  

The number d of splits in each tree, controlling complexity. D=1 is good, and creates a stump - a single split. Also known as the interaction depth, it controls the interaction order of the boosted model. 

 

Variable importance measure: Detecting which predictors matter the most - RSS decrease over splitting a predictor is recorded. Or, for classification, record the amount the Gini index has dropped over a given predictor, averaged over all B trees. 

 

 

Appendix: 

Extra trees: Extremely randomized trees - even weaker trees, but use even more estimators in the ensemble. Not only features and samples shown to the tree are randomized, but also the growing of individual trees is random. Available in scikit learn.  

 

Boosting for classification: If binary, let's make it bipolar: {-1,1}. Now, assign weights to the training points in the training sample based on how difficult those training points are for classification, and based on those weights train sequential classifiers, and those classifiers can be assigned weights. For prediction, a weighted sum of the decisions of those classifiers can be used. 

Data that are difficult are up-weighted, correctly classified data from the previous round are left alone or down weighted.  

For example, AdaBoost. He explains it in the lecture.  

 

Stacking: Use the output of multiple classifiers as input to a meta-model. We 'stack' the meta-model on top of the base models. Uses the predictions of knn, svm, etc as features.  

The meta-model could be something simple like linear regression of the model predictions. At worst, it's going to have the error of the worst model, but no worse. But, it will prefer the overfit models. Thus, inputs to the meta-model should not have seen the labels for the data points themselves - aka, keep an extra training set on hand for a target label. Note: don't re-use your base-learner as the meta-model. However, stacking isn't usually all that beneficial, and it has a large computational cost and makes the result less interpretable.  

 

Adaptive meta-learners: A function that implements different models on each section of the feature space, based on which model is more accurate in that region.  

 

 

 

CHAPTER 9: Support Vector Machines 

The SVM is a generalization of the maximal margin classifier.

Beta is called the normal vector - it points in a direction orthogonal to the surface of the hyperplane. 

 

Maximal Margin Classifier 

 

The maximal margin hyperplane is the separating hyperplane that is farthest from the training observations. Thus, we can classify a test observation based on which side of the hyperplane it lies - making it a maximal margin classifier. The points which determine the location of the hyperplane are known as the support vectors. 

 

When y1 … yn are {-1,1}, and X has p dimensions, then the maximal margin hyper plane is the solution to the optimization problem:  

 

 

M is the margin to the hyperplane. All of the betas must add up to 1 - this is included so that the perpendicular distance from the ith observation to the hyperplane is given by  

 

The non-separable case: When no separating hyperplane exists, there is no maximal margin classifier. Then, the above set of equations has no solution with M > 0. However, we can develop a hyperplane that almost separates the calsses, using a soft margin. This generalization is known as the support vector classifier.  

 

Support Vector Classifier (or Soft Margin Classifier) 

MMC's are also extremely sensitive to single observations, suggesting that it is prone to overfitting. Perhaps we don't want to fit an absolutely perfect hyperplane, but instead one that is more robust to individual observations and better at classifying most of the training observations.  

Thus, we can allow some points to fall within the margin (a soft margin) or even on the wrong side of the hyperplane.  

 

…where C is a nonnegative tuning parameter. Epsilon are slack variables that allow individual observations to be on the wrong side of the margin or the hyperplane. Once this hyperplane is created, we define a test observation based on which side of the hyperplane it lies, as usual.  

If epsiloni = 0 then the ith observation is on the correct side of the margin. If it's > 0 then the observation is on the wrong side of the margin, aka it "violated" the margin. If it's > 1 then it's on the wrong side of the hyperplane.  

C bounds the sum of the epsilons, and so it determines the number and severity of the violations to the margin and hyperplane that we will tolerate. It is the budget for the amount that the margin can be violated by the n observations. As C increases we become more tolerant of violations to the margin, and so the margin widens. It is chosen via cross validation, and controls the bias-variance trade-off.  

 

Now, the support vectors are those observations that lie directly on the margin or on the wrong side, which affect the location of the classifier. The more observations violating the margin, the more support vectors we have, and the lower the variance of the classifier. The fact that observations far from the margins are basically irrelevant to the classifier makes this method unique compared to, for example, LDA, but similar to logistic regression.

The Kernel Trick 

Thus, the Support Vector Machine is an extension of the SVC that results from enlarging the features space in a specific way, using kernels. The idea is that we may want to enlarge our features space in order to accommodate a non-linear boundary between the classes, and the kernel approach is a computationally efficient way of doing so.

Multi-class and Multilabel Classification 

What about when we have more than two classes to predict? It's not ideal, but here's a few ideas: 

 

One-Versus-One Classification: If there are K classes, this approach constructs (K over 2) SVMs, each of which compares a pair of classes. We classify a test observation using each of these classifiers, and tally the number of times the observation is assigned to each of the K classes.  

One-Versus-All Classification: Fit K SVMs, each time comparing one of the K classes to the remaining K-1 classes. We assign an observation to the class for each the beta value equations is largest, giving us a higher level of confidence that the observation belongs to that class. 

 

From lecture: 

 

OVO when K is small, OVA when K is large. 

 

Multilabel classification: Assigns to each sample a set of target labels. These are predicting properties of a data point that are not mutually exclusive - ie, a text might be about any of religion, politics, finance, and/or education. 

  1. 1.Problem transformation 

    1. a.Binary Relevance 

      1. i.Treat each label as a separate classification. With a test point, ask each of these classifiers to predict y.  

        1. 1.Problem - are labels correlated? Thus, the next approach: 

    2. b.Classifier Chains 

      1. i.First classifier is trained on features, and consecutive classifiers are trained on the features and the labels of the previous classifiers. 

        1. 1.Thus for correlation, each classifier is considering each previous classifier's label, so it can consider these correlations. 

    3. c.Label Powerset 

      1. i.Transform the problem into a multi-class problem with one multi-class classifier is trained on all unique label combinations found in the training data. 

        1. 1.IF X1 and X3 have the same labels then they're in the same class. 

        2. 2.Criticism: Data may not have all possible classifications. With n labels, there's 2^n classes, and they may not all be in the training data, or there are few instances of each.  

  2. 2.Adapted Algorithms 

    1. a.Multilabel kNN 

      1. i.Doing kNN for each label, however, it uses prior probabilities and ranks labels. Confusing, but it's ok scikit learn. 

    2. b.Decision trees, modified to calculate purity in each region. 

  3. 3.Ensemble approaches 

    1. a.AdaBoost.MH and AdaBoost.MR - trees.

  1. 1.Accuracy score / Exact match metric: Must be an exact match between prediction and truth. Too strict. 

    1. a.So, let's use Hamming Loss: the fraction of the wrong labels to the total number of labels. 

 

SVC vs Logistic Regression: SVMs are better for linearly separable data. Logistic regression is better for probabilities than SVMs. But, probabilities can be gotten from SVMs by distances between hyperplane and datapoint - using the logistic equation function.  

 

The Vapnik-Chervonenkis Dimension (not in textbook) 

The VC dimension is a measure of the complexity of a space of functions that can be learned by a classification algorithm. It quantifies what type of data/boundaries a classifier can learn. 

Shattering: If no matter how you assign labels to X (positive, negative…), the model learns them perfectly without training error.  So, the VC dimension is the maximum number of points that can be arranged so that f shatters them. IE: a linear classifier separates positive and negative data points, can a linear classifier possibly separate them in any orientation, NO MATTER how the points are classified? Well, it turns out that in 3 dimensions the VC classifier is 3 - also the number of betas in that equation (p+1).

CHAPTER 10: Unsupervised Learning 

Unsupervised learning is when we only have a set of features Xp measured on n variables, without a response Y. We're not interested in predicting anything, rather we're looking to discover interesting things about the measurements on Xp. Cool visualization skills? Subgroups? Anyways, the best methods for this type of exploration are principal components analysis (for data visualization or pre-processing) and clustering (for discovering unknown subgroups in data).  

 

Problems: Unsupervised learning is very subjective, and there's not a clear cut goal. It's exploratory data analysis. There's no way to cross validate an independent data set.  

 

Clustering: A partition of the data set into distinct groups so that the observations within each group are similar to each other. There are two main clustering methods: 

  1. 1.K-means clustering, where we partition the observations into a pre-specified number of clusters.  

  2. 2.Hierarchical clustering, where we create a tree-like dendogram that is created because we do not know in advance how many clusters we want. It allows us to view at once the clusterings obtained for each possible number of clusters, from 1 to n. 

 

K-Means Clustering 

For K distinct, non-overlapping clusters: 

  1. 1.Specify the desired number of clusters K 

  2. 2.The K means algorithm will assign each observation to exactly one of the K clusters.  

 

First, C1, …, CK denotes sets containing the indices of the observations in each cluster. They satisfy: 

  1. 1.The union of all C's = {1,…,n) - aka, each observation belongs to at least one of the K clusters. 

  2. 2.The clusters are nonoverlapping. 

 

The idea is that a good clustering is one for which the within-cluster variation is as small as possible. This is denoted as W(CK), a measure of the amount by which the observations within a cluster differ from each other, hence, let's:  

 

So, let's define within-cluster variation using squared Euclidean distance: 

 where |CK| denotes the number of observations in the kth cluster. Combining these two equations gives us, finally: 

However, there are so many different ways to cluster into groups - K to the n number, in fact. So instead,  

 

Because this finds a local rather than a global optimum, the results obtained will depend on the initial random cluster assignment of each observation in Step 1. Thus, you should run the algorithm multiple times from different random initial configurations and choose the best solution.  

 

(from lecture) K-Medoid Clustering - the medoid is a data point that has the smallest average dissimilarity with other data points in the cluster. This way we limit the center to be one of the data points. The "average" doesn't always make sense in the problem.  

 

 

Hierarchical Clustering 

The problem with K means clustering is that it requires us to specify the number of clusters K beforehand. Hierarchical clustering is an alternative approach that does not have this specification. Another advantage is that it results in a nice tree-based representation of the observations called a dendogram. 

We'll use bottom up or agglomerative clustering - the most common type - called so because the dendogram is built starting from the leaves and comining clusters up to the trunk.  

 

Here's how to interpret them: Each leaf is an observation, and as we ascend the leaves fuse into branches, which means the observations are similar to one another. The earlier the fusions occur, the more similar the groups of observations are to each other. Be sure to not take horizontal nearness as similarity, but only how high up on the graph two branches intersect. To identify clusters from a dendogram, we'll create a horizontal cut across the dendogram: 

The distinct sets of observations beneath the cut can be interpreted as clusters. The height of the cut determines the number of clusters, similar to choosing K in K means clustering.  

 

The algorithm used to create a dendogram: Euclidean distance is used to define dissimilarity, usually. First, every point is a cluster. Then, the two most similar are clustered. Then again, etc. Once we start clustering groups of observations together, we must consider linkage, which defines the dissimilarity between two groups of observations. The four most common types are complete, average, single, and centroid.  

 

Also, instead of Euclidean dissimilarity, we might use correlation-based distance, which considers two observations similar if their features are correlated, even though they're far apart in terms of Euclidean distance. Meaning, if they follow the same paths (ie the same purchasing tendencies, etc) even though their magnitudes are different. Finally, scaling can be very important, and is decided based on the needs of the application.  

 

Practical Issues in Clustering 

  1. 1.Small decisions with big consequences 

    1. a.Standardize observations or features? Centered? 

    2. b.Which dissimilarity method? Linkage method? Dendogram cut location? 

    3. c.How many K clusters? 

      1. i.Answer to these above: We try several different choices - there is no right answer. 

  2. 2.Validating the clusters obtained 

    1. a.Are we clustering the noise? Would the same method on test data look similar? 

  3. 3.Other considerations 

    1. a.Should every single observation be in a cluster? That may distort their regularity. Perhaps consider a soft version of clustering. 

  4. 4.Slow your roll 

    1. a.Always try many methods!

Should be a great calculation method, right? Unfortunately, this will overfit, maximize when K=n. We can use the elbow of the scree plot to determine a good number of clusters.

Gap statistic: How much W(K) drops at any one K is valuable information. Here's how we do it: Compare W(K) to Wu(K), the variation we'd see if all points were distributed uniformly. We then define the gap for K as:

Silhouette Analysis: A method of interpretation and validation of consistency within clusters of data, it provides a graphical representation of how well each object lies within its cluster. It's a wrapper method, it doesn't depend on the clustering method that is used. First we calculate ai, the average distance between xi and all other data within the same cluster. This tells how well xi is assigned to a cluster. We also define bi as the lowest average distance of xi to all points in any other cluster of which xi is not a member. This is then called the "neighboring cluster" of xi because it is the next best fit for that point. We now define silhouette: 

This will be 1 when xi is appropriately clustered, 0 when it is on the border between the two clusters, and -1 when it's likely unclustered. The average si over a cluster measures how tightly grouped all the data in the cluster are, and over the dataset it measures how well done the clustering has been performed. Gives plots like this: 

 

 

Cross-validation: Data is partitioned into v folds, and these folds are used for CV. "The value of an objective function is calculated for the test set," - ie the sum of the squared distances to the centroids for k-means. Each of these v values are calculated and averaged for each number of clusters c, and the number of clusters is chosen such that any further increase in cluster numbers only slightly reduces the objective function (as decided by a scree plot). 

 

Variable selection for clustering: Do you really need all 3 dimensions? Sometimes a subset, like just 1 dimension, defines the clusters. Sometimes which dimension you choose determines the number of clusters and the assignments. But, can feature subset selection and clustering use different criteria? For example, to cluster we use within cluster variation, but to evaluate afterwards we use average silhouette. But inside subset selection, we should re-cluster and determine the K again.  

 

Principal Component Analysis 

Recall that Principal Components were discussed in Chapter 6. When faced with a large set of correlated variables, principal components allow us to summarize this set with a smaller number of representative variables that collectively explain most of the variability in the original set. Their directions are those in which the data shows the most variation.  

 

Principal Component Analysis refers to the process by which principal components are computed, and their use in understanding data. It is necessary because visualizing p dimensions is impossible, so we must find a way to reduce these predictors down to a lower dimension and still capture as much of the information as possible.  

PCA provides a tool to do this. The idea is that each of the n observations lives in p-dimensional space, but not all of these dimensions are equally interesting - when we define interesting as the amount that the observations vary along each dimension. Each of the dimensions found by PCA is a linear combination of the p features. These dimensions are principal components. 

 

The first principal component of a feat of features X1 … Xp is the normalized linear combination of the features  

…that has the largest variance.  

"Normalized" here means that  

 because otherwise these values could be too large and create large variance. These phi values are referred to as the loading vector of the first principal component.  

 

Now if we assume that each of the variables in X has been centered to have mean zero, we look for the linear combination of the sample feature values of the form  

 that has the largest sample variance. Or to rephrase it, the principal component loading vector solves the optimization problem:  

The average of all of the n z values for the first principal component will be zero. These z values for each of 1 to n are the scores of the first principal component. The loading vector defines a direction in feature space along which the data vary the most. If we project the X values onto this direction, the projected values are the principal component scores z themselves.  

 

The second principal component Z2 then is the linear combination of X's that has maximal variance out of all linear combinations that are uncorrelated with Z1, thus making them orthogonal to the direction of (phi1). Once this is found, and all desired larger components, we can project them against each other to view the data.  

 

Further comments: The variables should be centered to have mean zero. Scaling makes a big difference in the results, in contrast to linear regression. That's because different predictors have different units, ranges, and most importantly - variances. So, we scale everything to have a standard deviation of 1 - usually - unless they all have the same units in the first place.  

 

Here's a question - how much of the information in a given data set is lost by projecting the observations onto the first few principal components? Specifically, what is the proportion of variance explained (PVE) by each principal component? It is this:  

We visualize a scree plot, which explains the PVE from each component, to determine how many components we should use to get a good understanding of the data.

Novelty Detection 

An unsupervised learning problem about the identification of new or unknown data or signals that a machine learning system is not aware of during training. If you've clustered but now you're searching a larger population and you're not sure what you're looking at. In a traditional sense, this is too difficult to be formulated as a classification problem, unless we can collect and handle very large numbers of "novel" examples. But if we do it in a supervised way, we teach our algorithm to know what it doesn't know. 

 

Possible approaches: 

  1. 1.Density Estimation - Estimate a density based on training data. Threshold the estimated density for test points. 

  2. 2.Quantile Estimation - Estimate a quantile of the distribution underlying the training data. Attempt to find a small set S such that the probability that x is in S is equals to either 0 or 1. Check whether test points are inside or outside S. 

 

One Class Support Vector Machine (OCSVM) Algorithm - Maps input data into a high dimensional feature space via kernels. Iteratively finds the maximal margin in the hyperplane which best separates the training data from the origin. Solves optimization problem to find rule f with maximal margin:  

 

LESSON 9 - Semi-Supervised and Active Learning 

Semi-supervised learning is supervised learning with additional unlabeled data, or unsupervised learning with additional labeled data.  

 

 

Semi-Supervised Learning 

We might draw a classification boundary between two sets of labeled data points. When we then add many unlabeled data points, they appear to belong to each of these two classes, but having this extra information allows us to draw the classification boundary more accurately. We call this "intuition."  

 

Transductive - We produce a label only for the available unlabeled data. This is not a classifier. 

 

Inductive - We not only produce a label for the unlabeled data, but we also produce a classifier. Here's more on inductive semi-supervised learning: 

  • •Classifier based methods (self training) - Start from initial classifiers and iteratively enhance them. 

  • •Data based methods - Discover an inherent geometry in the data and exploit it in finding a good classifier. 

 

Self-Training 

An inductive process and a classifier based method.  

 

Yarowsky Algorithm: We train a supervised model on labeled data L, then we test unlabeled data U. We add the most confidently classified members of U to L. We then repeat the process. But early misidentifications could lead to bad classification, thus: 

 

Refinement: Reduce the weight of unlabeled data to increase power of more accurate labeled data. 

 

Advantages to self training 

  • •The simplest semi-supervised learning method. 

  • •It's a wrapper method that applies to existing, complex classifiers. 

  • •It's often used in real tasks like natural language processing. 

 

Disadvantages to self training 

  • •Early mistakes could reinforce themselves. 

    • ○There are heuristic solutions to this, e.g. to "un-label" an instance if its confidence falls below a certain threshold. 

 

Co-Training 

Let's define some terms. An instance (x=x1, x2). This contains two sufficient sets of features. Each set of features is called a view (from x1 to x2).  

Two views are independent given the label: 

Two views are consistent given: 

This means, if you build a classifier using one of them, it's the same classifier you'll get from using the other one. 

 

Here's co-training: C1 is a classifier trained on view 1, C2 is a classifier trained on view 2. Allow each of them to label some instances. The instances that we are confident in are added into the pool of training data, and the process repeats.  

Here's an example of co-learning for classifying web pages: The first set of attributes describes the content of the web pages, and the second set describes links from other pages.  

We must assume independence between these, as this will reduce the probability of the models agreeing on incorrect labels. 

 

Yarowsky + Co-Training: Like the standard Yarowsky, but the view is switched in each iteration, meaning only one classifier classifies in each interation, but they both then learn from it. This uses all of the unlabeled (or probabilistically labeled) data for training. In each iteration, only one of the classifiers labels the data.  

 

General Multiview learning: Train multiple diverse models on L. Those instances in U which most models agree on are placed in L. 

 

Semi-supervised SVM: We maximize the margin of both L and U. The decision surface is placed in non-dense spaces. This assumes that the classes are well-separated. It can also try to simultaneously maintain class proportion on both sides similar to labeled proportions.  

 

Cluster and Label Approach: We start with the assumption that the clusters coincide with decision boundaries. First we cluster labeled and unlabeled data. For each cluster, we train a classifier based on the labeled points within that cluster. We then label all data in each cluster using the classifier designed for that cluster. Finally, we train a model based on the whole data. 

 

Clustering as preprocessing for supervised learning.  

  1. 1.First, cluster your training data. Naturally, you do not need labels, just clusters. 

  2. 2.For each cluster, train a supervised learner. We are assuming that different models apply to different regions of the feature space. 

  3. 3.If you have a test point X*, determine in which cluster it resides. Then, use the model of that cluster to predict the label of X*.  

 

Active Supervised Learning 

  • •Supervised learning: You have an oracle expert labeler who knows the labels.  

    • ○You take a random sample, blindly, and the oracle gives you the labeled data.  

  • •Semi-supervised learning: The oracle has access to the structure of the unlabeled data.  

  • •Active learning: Again, you have an oracle that knows the labels. The active learner has a model on some randomly labeled data, and the active learner has the luxury of inspecting unlabeled data and telling the oracle which labels it wants, ie which are informative for its learning.  

    • ○Again, the active learner inspects the data, queries (asks about the data for the ones it wants), the oracle gives the labels, the active learner updades its model, and does it again.  

 

Active learning vs random sampling: Adding more data points improves accuracy, as we see in the learning curve. For the same amount of data, the active learner will learn faster. With infinite data, the two curves (active and passive) will converge, but with a limited budget for labeling data, we should do it in an active way. 

 

From a video: A human labels some data, and a machine learning algorithm is created from it. This algorithm states confidence, and when confidence is low, it sends it back to the human for labeling, but when confidence is high, it labels it itself. These are then plugged back into the training data, and the process is repeated.  

 

Stream-Based vs. Pool-Based Active Learning 

  • •Stream-based active learning 

    • ○One unlabeled example at a time, we decide whether to query the label or ignore it. 

  • •Pool-based active learning 

    • ○A large unlabeled pool of examples at a time. Rank examples in order of informativeness, then query the labels for the most informative examples (I think query means, send this back to the human (oracle) to be labeled). 

 

Query Selection Strategies 

Any active learning algorithm requires a query selection strategy. There are many examples: 

  • •Uncertainty sampling: Select examples which the model is the most uncertain about, based on distance from hyperplane or using label probability. 

  • •Query by committee: Uses a committee of models. This committee is constructed by sampling different models from the model distribution, or using ensemble methods like bagging/boosting. All these models vote their predictions on the unlabeled pool, and the examples with maximum disagreement are chosen for labeling. Then, each model is retrained again. 

    • ○Both uncertainty and QBC are affected by outliers, which is dangerous. One solution is to test how a labeled example affects the model itself, as explained by the next two bullet points: 

  • •Expected model change: select the example whose inclusion brings about the maximum change in the model. 

  • •Expected error reduction: Select the example that reduces the expected generalization error the most 

  • •Variance reduction: Select examples that reduce the model variance by maximizing the Fisher information of model parameters 

  • •Density weighting: Weight the informativeness of an example by its average similarity to the entire unlabeled pool of examples 

 

LESSON 10: Neural Networks 

 

Perceptron - an algorithm for binary classification that uses a linear prediction function:  

This is a step function - it's 1 if the top, it's -1 if it's the bottom. So, the two classes are +1 and -1.  

These betas are called weights. They're unknown, and what we have to learn. Perceptron learns these parameters to best separate the instances of -1 and 1. Here's the process of how it learns: 

  1. 1.Initialize all weights (Beta) to 0, or randomly. 

  2. 2.Iterate through the training data. For each training instance, classify the instance. If the prediction is correct, do nothing. If the prediction is incorrect, modify the weights by using the update rule.  

  3. 3.Repeat #2 many times. 

 

What's this Update Rule? Well, if the classifier predicted negative when the truth is positive, the Beta weights are adjusted so that this function value moves towards positive, and vice versa. 

 

 

From now on, we'll call Beta w for weight, and we'll call beta zero b for bias.  

 

Like SVC, Perceptron is a linear classifier. However, SVC's optimization needs all data to yield a classifier, making it a batch algorithm. However, Perceptron adapts its weights online, based on the data points that are presented to it. That makes it an online algorithm.  

 

If the training instances are not linearly separable, the classifier will inevitably get some predictions wrong. There must be a stopping criteria for when the algorithm will stop making updates, or it will get stuck updating forever - such as a maximum number of iterations (show one data point) or epochs (show the whole data set). 

 

Multiple classifications can be made by using multiple hyperplanes. The weights associated with each hyperplane can be represented as the columns of a weight matrix W, and the biases can be stored in vector b. The vector of errors at epoch (i) is called e(i).  

Or, let's add in alpha, which is a learning rate or step size: 

 

When wj is updated to be more positive or negative, alpha controls the size of the change that is made. Earlier this was automatically set to 0.5. If alpha is too small, the algorithm will be slow due to small updates, but if alpha is large the algorithm will be slow due to constant overshooting. Solution: Start large, then reduce it as: 

 

Learning rate: First explore some W's. Then, exploit at the end (Exploration / Exploitation). Do this with a variable learning rate - large at first, reducing after more iterations (ie the equation just above).  

 

 

Adaptation in neural systems: the perceptron learning rule acts like a simple neural system, in that it adapts its weights based on the error that is a result of mismatch between its output and the desired output. This is the basis of supervised learning with neural networks. 

 

Consider: If the training set is not linearly separable, the perceptron rule never converges. Hence, it will have a large classification error. The general solution is to represent the data in a feature space where they are linearly separable. One idea is to use layers of perceptrons and adjust their weights to learn the feature representations.  

 

Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) - Each layer may have a different number of neurons (There can be other activation functions than the "sign (threshold)" function). They're represented as nested functions, such as:  

Where each g is a layer of neurons with weight matrix W and bias vector b and activation function f. This all results in the definition of the output of the ith layer a(i) as:  

MLP's are also called Feedforward Neural Networks. The weights can be learned to utilize an MLP for either classification or regression.  

 

Types of activation functions that are often used: Sigmoid functions, and tanh sigmoid functions have been used for classification and regression. More recently, the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLu) is commonly used.  

 

MLP's for regression: Any smooth function can be approximated with precision using an MLP with two layers: A hidden layer of smooth nonlinear functions (ie sigmoids) and an output layer of smooth functions (even linear functions). This makes them universal approximators. 

MLP's for classification: They can be used with at least a hidden layer of smooth nonlinear functions (ie sigmoids), an output layer of linear functions followed by threshold functions. Classes will be encoded using either binary encoding or One Hot encoding, and this will create the desired outputs as vecors representing each class.  

 

The Architecture of a Neural Network 

  • •Choice of depth (number of layers) of network. Deeper networks have fewer units in each layer, and they generalize well to the test set. However, they are more difficult to train. 

  • •Choice of width (number of neurons) of each layer. 

 

Training MLP's - They're trained using optimization algorithms. These algorithms need calculation of gradients to be numerically solved. Backpropagation (of errors) is a wonderful method to calculate gradients used to adjust the weights in MLPs to learn regression and classification tasks.  

 

With a training set {x(1), y(1)}, … , {x(N), y(N)}, we would like to minimize some objective function J by finding suitable weight matrices for each layer. One suitable objective function J is the expected sum of square errors:  

We don’t know J at each moment that some pair x(k) and y(k) become available, so we approximate J based on the error of the network with respect to the pair x(k) and y(k). 

"S" are called sensitivities, they're computed by starting at the last layer and propagating backwards through the network to the first layer. We present each randomly selected raining sample or batch of samples and use the forward and backwards paths to calculate sensitivities and update the weights. This is called an iteration. Each time the whole training set is presented to the network is called an epoch. Training the network requires multiple epochs.  

 

Regularization methods: We can add L1 and L2 regularizers to the objective function in back propagation, and "empirical" regularization is also very popular.  

 

Adding noise to the input is helpful, including flipping, rotating and cropping images. But don't add so much that points cross the separation boundary. This is all equilivant to adding a regularization term. But, in flipping images, be careful of flipping b indo a d, etc. Also, don't overfit - use a validation set to decide when to stop the algorithm.
